chapters.text: Mia froze at the entrance to the school gym, watching the other eighth graders practicing their routines for the upcoming dance competition. Everyone seemed to have a partner already—everyone except her. She spotted Tyler, the new boy who'd moved here last month, sitting alone on the bleachers. He was scrolling through his phone, seemingly unbothered by the chaos around him. Mia had barely spoken two words to him, but she was running out of options. The competition was in three weeks, and without a partner, she couldn't enter. As she walked toward him, her best friend Zoe grabbed her arm. "I have the perfect solution," Zoe whispered excitedly. "Just ask Tyler to be your dance partner and pretend you're dating. The judges love couples, and you'll stand out from everyone else. It's just for show—what could go wrong?"

Mia took a deep breath and stepped into the gym, her eyes scanning the crowded space for anyone who might also need a partner. The colorful decorations hung from the ceiling, and the squeaking of sneakers against the polished floor filled her ears. Coach Martinez was clapping her hands at the front, directing pairs of students through the basic steps. Mia spotted Jake, the new boy who had transferred last month, standing awkwardly by the water fountain. He wasn't dancing with anyone either. Maybe this was her chance. She walked over, her heart beating fast like a drum. "Do you need a partner?" she asked, trying to sound casual. Jake looked relieved and nodded. "I was hoping someone would ask," he said with a smile. Mia grinned back. Perhaps this competition wouldn't be so bad after all. They walked to an empty corner of the gym to practice.

Mia and Jake walked to an empty corner of the gym to practice. The polished wooden floor squeaked under their sneakers as they found a spot away from the other dancers. Jake awkwardly placed his hand on Mia's waist while she rested her hand on his shoulder. "One, two, three, one, two, three," Jake counted under his breath as they began to move. Their first few steps were clumsy, with Mia wincing when Jake accidentally stepped on her toes. "Sorry," he whispered, his face turning red. Mia just smiled and kept going. After a few minutes, they started to find their rhythm. The music from the speakers echoed through the gym as they spun and stepped together. Ms. Garcia, the dance teacher, nodded approvingly as she passed by. Maybe this partnership wasn't going to be so bad after all.

Mia watched as Ethan demonstrated a complicated spin move, his sneakers squeaking against the gym floor. He caught her staring and grinned, motioning for her to try it too. Taking a deep breath, Mia copied his movements, wobbling slightly but managing to complete the turn without falling. "Not bad for a beginner," Ethan said, offering her a high-five. They practiced for another hour, laughing whenever one of them messed up. By the end of the session, they had created a short routine that actually looked pretty good. As they packed up their water bottles and dance notes, Mia spotted the drama club's prop box in the corner of the gym, filled with fake crowns, shields, and a plastic sword. She smiled to herself, feeling more confident about the competition. With Ethan as her partner, maybe they had a chance at winning after all.

Mia watched as Ethan demonstrated a perfect spin, his movements smooth and confident. She couldn't believe her luck finding a partner who actually knew what he was doing. The gym echoed with music as they practiced their routine, their steps becoming more synchronized with each attempt. Other students glanced their way, surprised by how well they worked together. Even Ms. Parker, the dance teacher, nodded approvingly as they completed a difficult sequence. Sweat beaded on Mia's forehead as they practiced for the third hour straight, but she didn't mind. The competition was only two weeks away, and they needed all the practice they could get. When Ethan suggested they add a dramatic dip at the end of their routine, Mia agreed enthusiastically. They tried it once, twice, three times until they got it right. The other dancers were good, but Mia and Ethan were becoming great.

The other dancers were good, but Mia and Ethan were becoming great. Every afternoon, they practiced in the school gym until their feet ached and their shirts stuck to their backs with sweat. Mia counted the beats while Ethan spun her across the polished floor, their movements getting smoother each day. Ms. Rivera, their dance teacher, often stopped other pairs to watch them demonstrate the trickier steps. "Look at their timing," she would say, pointing to the wall clock for emphasis. "Perfect synchronization!" The competition was only two weeks away, and Mia no longer felt the panic that had gripped her that first day. Instead, a new feeling bubbled up inside her whenever Ethan took her hand—something warm and fluttery that made her cheeks turn pink. She tried to focus only on the dance steps, but sometimes caught herself smiling for no reason at all.

The music swelled around them as Mia and Jake moved across the gym floor, their steps perfectly in sync. When Jake spun her, Mia caught glimpses of their classmates watching with wide eyes. The same people who had laughed weeks ago now clapped as they finished their routine. After the final pose, Jake gave her hand a quick squeeze. "We did it," he whispered. Ms. Garcia announced the winners, and when she called their names for second place, Mia couldn't believe it. They walked forward together to accept their trophy, a small silver dancer that sparkled under the gym lights. Outside after the competition, a gentle breeze stirred the leaves on the school lawn. Mia realized that finding a dance partner had given her something more valuable than just a trophy - it had given her confidence and a new friend. "Same time next week?" Jake asked with a grin, and Mia nodded happily.
